div2.p: Prometo lealdad á la Bandera de los E.U. de A. y la republica que ella representa una nacion indivicible que garantiza libertad y justicia para todos. Un juramento es una promesa solemne. La lealdad se inifica fidelidad inalterable. En este juramento prometemos solamente que de pensamiento, palabra y obra respetaremos la Bandera y el Pais que ella representa. Esto republica es una nacion indivisible, que ofrece libertad y justicia para todos sus habitantes.
La Bandera es el simbolo de nuestra libertad y de nuestra fe con nuestro corazon henchido de agradesimiento juramos defenderla y debemos sentirnos orgullosus de vivi r bajo su sombra
injusticia y da la crueldad, sino que estará dispuesto á pelear, si fuere necesaria, para mantender poderoso y libre este paíz, los E.U. de America, que es también su patria.

El Nacimiento de los E. U. fue por virtud del descubrimiento hecho por Cristobal Colon el 12 de Octubre en 1492, que este paiz llamado mas tarde E. U. de A. fue poblado; otros viajeros habian desembarcado en este continente, pero nunca establecieron colonia alguna. El dinero para el viaje de Colon fue suministrado por la Reyna Isabl de España.

MAS de cien años trascurieron antes de que llegaron á estas comarcas los verdaderos colonizadores que bautizaron con el apelativo de colonias los sitios en donde se establesieron. Estas colonias vineron á ser mas tarde los E. U. de A.

la mayor parte de los Colonos vinieron de Inglatierra. el Rey continió siendo su soberano aún despues de haber desembarcado ellos en este paiz, y el inglés vino á ser el idioma nacional. Algunos colones holandeses se establecieron en lo que es hoy Nueva York, otros colones suecos en Delaware, y muchos alemanes en Pensilbania a la ves en todas las colonias se en contraban súbditos escoseses é irlandeses.

los ingleses establesieron su primera colonia en 1607 en Jamestown, estado de Virginia. Ellos cruzaron el Atlántico en tiempo de hinvierno, haciendo la travecia en tres barcos pequeños llamados la Sarah Constant, el Goodspeed y el Discovery. En dicho barcos hicieron el viaje cinto cinco colonos comandados por el Capitan Christopher Newport. MÁS tarde, despues de desembarcar, los colonos quedaron al mando del Valeroso y famoso Capitan John Smith. Loas Colonas tardaron cuatro meses en cruzar el océano. En el viaje fueron azotados por varias tempestades y sufrieron unimelrables contratiempos Finalmente el 26 de Abril, llegaron á las plallas de de Virginia y de á alli siguieron navegando,
Pagina 14 navegando por ciento sesenta kilometros á través de la Bahia de Chesapeake y aguas arriba del Rio James en busca de un sitio adecuado en donde poder estableser una Colonia. El 13 de Mayo encontraron el sitio deseado, al cual dieron el nombre de Jamestown en honor del Rey James de Inglatierra. Alli desembarcaron y comenzaron imediatamen te á constituir su propio govierno.

Esta parte del pais estaba habitada únicamente por indios y animales salbajes, y en ella no habia ni ciudades ni aldeas ni casas. Todo eran espesos bosques, pantanos y el ancho rio que coria corria majestouoso en sus cercanias. Era el anocheser en medio de una gran arboleda los viajeros cortaron un arbol gigantesco y utilizaron su tronco para contruir sobre de el un altar de las ramas de otro arbol colgaron una vela para formar un sestandarte y celebraron alli un servicio religioso. Asi con la formasión de un govierno y la celebracion de unnacio la primera colonia inglesa permanente en America.

No paso mucho tiempo antes de que los colonos volvieron a exprimentar contratiempos y sufriendo sufrimientos. Pronto aprendieron que sólo á fuerza de trabajo podían subsistir y que tenian que cortar árbóles, desmontar la tierra, labrar el suelo y cultivar maiz. Ellos no habian traido esposas ni hijos que pudieran ayudarles á construir casas, pronto agotaron las provisiones que habían traido de Inglatierra. Y al prencipio no pudieron producir suficiente maiz para atender á su sustento. Entonces sobrevino una terrible época de hambre y desolacion que ellos llamaron la “Hora del Hombre” y en tonces la cual muchos de ellos perecieron y varios otros fueron asesinados por los indios. Desesperados con tantos reveces los colonos resolvieron regresas á su paiz, se aproximaba á la desembocadura se encontraron con un buque ingles cargado de provisiones. Esto fue su salvasion.

Y desde entonces la colonia de Jamestown comenzo a florecer y prosperar, en poco tiempo surgieron otras colonias y aument'o el numero de colonos
pagina 15 procedentes de Inglatierra. La gran Colonia de Virginia quedo fundada difinitivamente, en el 1619 los havitantes de ella celebraron la primera asamblea reprecentativa en America. Cada una de las Colonias designó does de sus miembros para hacerse representar en ella. La asamblea se reunío en Jamestown y expidio las leyes que debian regir los destinos de la Colonia. Como los ingleses creian firmemente en el govierno popular trajeron consigo sus propias leyes y sus instituciones libres.

La segunda Colonia inglesa permanente fue fundada en 1620. En Playmouth, estado de Massachusetts por los “Padres peregrinos”. Ellos vinieron a los E. U. pues deseaban hallar un lugar en donde pudieran venerar 'a Dios segun los dictados de su propia conciencia, cosa que no podían hacer en Inglatierra. Ellos zarparon del puerto inglés de Plymouth en un pequeño barco que llamaban ron el Mayflower. Y en helado del dia Mes de Diciembre desembarcaron en la costa rocallosa de la Nueva Inglatierra. A su desembarco no hallaron hombre blanco alguno que saliera á recivirlos y tuvieron desde un prencipio que comenzar á edeficar casas para albergarse en ellas con sus esposas y hijos.

La Vida les fue muy dura en los primeros años, pero ellos estaban resueltos á afrentar sufrimientos con tal de poder vener á Dios de acuerdo con sus creencias. Convencidos como estaban de que la mano del Todopoderoso los guiaba á un istante, su fe les daba fuerza para soportar los sufrimientos y las penalidades. Los E. U. honrabán siempre la memoria de esos peregrinos porque fueron ellos quieres trajieron consigo el amor á la liverta y quienes padesieron incensantemente para arraigar este amor en suelo Americano. Este amor á la livertad es el que ha hecho libre y el que ha dado grandeza á este propero pais. Veamos ahora cual era esta idea de libertad que profesaban los peregrinos. Ellos creian que el Pueblo tenia el derecho y la facultad de promulgar las leyes. Creian (over
tambien que estas leyes tenian por objeto el bien general, o sea el beneficio de todos. Y que cada cual debia obedecerlas puesto que eran dictados por el pueblo mismo. La verdadera libertad respeto los derechos ajenos, y esa fue la libertad que los Peregrinos vinieron á buscar en los E. U. y que no queriendo perderla prefirieron sufrir grandes penalidades.

Inglatierra poseia trece colonias en la Costa del Atlantico que crecieron y florecieron por espacio de 150 años. Muchas de las leyes de estas colonias no tenian reprecentacion. A ellas les parecia injusto que se les obligara á obedecer leyes dictadas sin su consentimiento, y cuando el Rey Jorge III quizo gobernar p despóticamente á Inglatierra y á los E. U. los colonos se sublebaron. La guerra de Independencia de los E.U. estallo empeso en abril de 1775. Los Colonos lucharon valerosamente durante siete años terribles bajo las ordenes del insigne General Gorge Washington, á quién hoy los norteamericanos llaman justamente el Padre de la Patria. Unieronse á ellos los ilustres generales franceses Lafatte y Rochambeu. Mas tarde Francia envió en su ayuda un ejercito y una armada El aleman Stuben, el bavaro DeKabby y el polaco Kosciusko fueron otros estranjeros que ayudaron a nuestros solados. La independencia de Inglatierra se obtuvo difenitivamente, y la paz se selló en 1783 El propósito de esta guerra de Independencia fue el de Prese curarvar los prencipios de los goviernos coloniales y mantener viva la libertad de los colonos que Jorge III habia tratado de coartar

Los norteamericanos aborrecieron aquellos revoluciones que tienden á destruir, á derrocar á sesinar, á saquear o á incendiar. La Victoria que ganaron los colones les dio la libertad para fundar un gobierno nacional sobre los cimientos ya sentados. dicha Victoria trasformo así las trece colonias independientes en lo que es hoy día de las E. U. de A., gobernados por la Constitución, he á qui el significado de la Revolucion Norteamerican ó guerra de la Independencia.

div2.head: La Declaracion de la Independencia
div2.p: Esta declaracion fue echa por las 13 estados originales de los E. U. de A. sancionada el 4 de Julio de 1776 por el Congreso Continental que se reunió en la ciudad de Filadelfía Estado de Pensilvania. La Declaración comienza expresando las razones por las cuales los Estados Unidos, compuestos en ese entonces; de solo trece estados, se vieron obligados á separarse de la Gran Bretaña, su Madre Patria

Nosotros sostenemos como verdades plamarias que todos los hombres han sido creados iguales por la naturaleza, que todos están dotados por su Creadir con ciertos derechos inalienables, entre los cuales figuran la Vida, la Libertad y la buena busca de la Felecidad. Que para asegurar estos derechos se han establecido entre los hombres los goviernos, que derivan sus ligítimas poderes del Consentimiento de los goviernos que siempre que una forma de govierno llega á convertirse en instrumento para destruir estos fines el pueblo tiene el derecho de cambiarla o de abolirla y de crear en su lugar un Nuevo Govierno.”
1. Todos los hombres han nacido iguales. Dios les ha Concedido ciertos derechos que no pueden usurpárselos, entre los cuales los principales son la vida, la libertad y la Felicidad.
2. Para gozar de estos derechos, los hombres establecen goviernos, que derrivan sus poderes del consentimiento de quienes son establecieron.
3. La Declaracion prosigue diciendo que el actual Rey de la Gran Bretaña, Jorge III, se ha negado á autorizar las leyes mas saludables y necesarias para el bien publico.

El Rey hizo que los jueces fueran responsables ante él únicamente por el tiempo de ocupación de sus cargos como por el montante de sus cargo sueldos, para que asi los habitantes de los estados no tuvieron nada que decir sobre sus propios (over

Suspendó el comercio de los estados con otras partes del mundo, para que pudieran traficar unicamente con la Gran Bretaña. Esto causó grandes trastornos al Pais.
Declaró que únicamente el tenia facultad para expedardir los lelley estaduales.
Impuso grávemenes sin el consentimiento del Pueblo.

En esta famosa declaración se citan muchos otros de los abusos é injusticias cometidas. La Declaración de Independencia prosige diciendo que el pueblo de los E. U. ha pedido, con la mayor humildad, que se le exonere de esas injusticias, pero la única respuesta que ha recibido es la de nuevas afrentas. Por ello no le quedó mas por hacer que libertar á los estados de sus vinculos para con la Corona Inglesa. He aqui la noble declaración que hicieron los reprecentantes de los E.U. en el Congreso Continental:

“Por todo ello, nosotros, los reprecentantes de los E.U.A., reunidos en samblea general, apelando al Supremo Juez del del Univerzo respecto á la autoridad de nuestras intenciones y en el nombre y por la autoridad del buen pueblo dé estas colonias unidas son, y por derecho deben ser, estados libres é independientes, que estan emancipadas de todo compromiso de lealdad hacia la corona britanica, y que todos los lazos politicos entre ellos y el page 19 estado de la Gran Bretaña deben quedar y han quedado completamente rotos, y que, como estados libres é independientes, tienen plena autoridad para declarar la guerra, concertar p la paz, celebrar tratados, establezer un sistema de comercio y realizar todos aquellos actos á que tienen derecho los estados independientes. En confirmación de lo dicho, y con una fé inquebrantdable en la protecsión de la Divina Providencia, enpeñamos mutuamente nuestras vidas y haciendas y nuestro hogar sagrado para el mantenimiento de la presente Declaracion.
La Declaracion de Independencia fue firmada por todas las cincuenta y ses 56 miembros de Congreso.

Los hombres son libres puesto que ellos son hijos de Dios, por lo tanto son iguales y dotados de una (over

div2.head: Cuna de la independencia
div2.p: En la calle Chestnut de la ciudad de Feladelfia, E. Pensilvania se encuentra un edificio de ladrillo, sencillo y muy antigo coronado por una torre. En el George Washington fue desinado comandante en jefe del ejército que luchó en la guerra de Independecia y que obtubo la victoria. En este mismo sitio se firmó la Declaración de Independencia en sus escalinatas se leyeron los preceptos de ella antepasados formularon y suscribieron la Carta Fundamental que nos gobierna, ó sea la Constitución de los E. U. A. En ese edeficio puede Ud. ver la Compana de la Libertad que anunció al mundo la Consumacion de la independencia. ESTA historica casa es un santuario venerado por todos los norteamericanos.

div2.head: La Bandera de los estados Unidos
div2.p: LA Bandera de los E. U. se llama á veces el Pabellón de las estrellas y Listas rojas y seis blancas representan los 13 Estados originales, un fondo azul con 48 estrellas representa los 48 estados de que hoy se compone la Republica.

Del cielo emos tomado las estrellas y el firmamento azul el rojo lo tomamos de nuestra madre patria. separandolo por listas blancas y mostrando de esta manera que nos hemos separado de ella y las listas blancas seguirán hasta la posteridad reprecentando la Libertad," dijo George Washington al hablar de la Bandera que el mismo había ayudado á deseñar para la nacion. Aun antes de que la Declaración de Independencia fuera firmada ya se había proyectado este pabellón que fue adoptado por el Congreso de los E. U. el 4 de julio de 1777 mediante la siguiente resolución:

una nueva constelacion habia nacido y toda su fe y sus esperanzas estan simbolizadas en su Bandera. De manera que cuando la Bandera pasa en procesiones ó revistas todos los que se hallen presentes deben cuadrase en posesion de atención y saludarla

Los hombres se quitaran el sombrero, las mujeres se pondran la mano derecha sobre el corazon, y las peronas que lleben uniforme deberán saludarla levantando la mano derecha hacía el Kepis. Asi como hay reglas de cortezía y de urbanidad para el trato entre personas tambien las hay para honrar nuestro pais y los ideales de defienden, las banderas viejas rotas ó sucias deben quemarse y nunca dejarse abandonadas ó usarse de ninguna manera
Page 22 irrespetuosa, no deje nunca que la bandera toque el suelo sino procure que esté siempre flameante y libre; y no la use jamás como colgadera o para fines decorativos. La banderia debera estar siempre ocupadando el puesto de honor a la derecha de la linia de marcha o delante de cualesquira obras pabellones en una procesion, á la derecha del orador cuando se despliego en una tribuna ó cuando mire hacia el auditorio, á la derecha del auditorio cuando tenga que izarse al mismo nivel de esto. La bandera á media asta es señal de duelo. Cuando se despliego de esta manera, deberá primero subirse por un instante hasta la punta del asta y luego bajarse hasta la mitad de ella. La bandera no deberá mantenerse desplegada sino entre la salida y la puesta del sol. Ella flota continuamente sobre el Capitolio de los E. U. y no se bjabaja sino cuando tiene que ser reemplazada por una nueva. Flota también sobre cualquiera de las dos Camaras cuando el Congreso esta en sesiones y sobre la Casa Blanca cuando el Presidente esta alli. En tiempo de guerra puede permanecer izada á todas horas. Esta Bandera es el simbolo de Libertad, Justicia e igualdad de oportunidades para todos los hombres, mujeres y niños. Con frecuencia á la Bandera se le llama cariñosamente “Old Glory.”

div2.head: El escudo de armas de los E.U.A.
div2.p: el 4 de Julio de 1776 despues de firmada la Declaración de Independencia, John Hancock, presidente del Congreso Continental, dijo: “Como ya somo una nación deseo saber vuestra opinion sobre lo siguiente Resuelbase que el Dr. Franklin, y los señores Thomas Jefferson y John Adams constituyeron una comisión encargada de idear un modelo para el escudo de armas de los E.U. de A. Este gran escudo lleva estampado la fecha del 4 de Julio de 1776 en que fue autorizada. Tiene trece listas que representan los 13 estados originales representados en el Congreso. Una aguia con un pasa la page 26 ramo de oliva en la garra derecha y un haz de 13 flechas en la izquierda segnifican que los los E.U. preferien la paz pero que á la vez estan preparados para la guerra. En el pico lleva un pergamino Con las palabras “El Pluribus Unum,” que significa “La unión hace la fuerza, es decir que se trata de un govierno formado por muchos estados. Este es el lema de los E.U.A. En la parte superior aparese una declaración Constelación que surge de entre las nubes, con 13 estrellas que simbolizan el nacimiento de una nueva nacion. En el reverso se ve una piramide impompleta sobre la cual aparece un ojo, que lo veo todo Con las palabras “Ammuit Coeptis” - El ha favorecido nuestro entendimiento·- La fecha del 4 de Julio 1776, se ve sobre la base de la pirámide y debajo el lema, Novas order Declorum- “un nuevo orden de los tiempos”- Así comenzo una nacion bajo la procteccsion de la Divina Providencia. Este escudo aparece en todos los Documentos officia es el simboliza la fe de la nacion;

div2.head: Govierno de los Estados Unidos, la Constitusion
div2.p:
Durante la guerra de Independencia la nueva nación formaba una asocación regida por los llamados artícolos de la Confederación. Los estados estaban representados por una asamblea de Ciudadanos denominadeaa Congreso Continental Una vez terminada la guerra se vio que esta forma degovierno era demasiado dibil. Los Estados no se hallaban verdaderamente unidos. Cada uno de ellos aspiraba a ejercer un gran poder, sus esfuerzos no estaban aunados: cada cual tenia su moneda propia y sus propias leyes acerca de su comercio con las demas estados de todo
sige page 27 cual resultaba una gran confución.

La nueva nacion necesitaba dinero para cubril los gastos del ejercito y la armada así como tambien para pagar las deudas contraidas durante la guerra. El Congreso no tenia facultad alguna para abigar á los estados á pagar sus contas l respectivas de estas deudas. Dado que la nacion no tinia governamento, es decir no habia presidente en Congreso no tenia facultad alguna para obligar á los estados á pagar sus autas respectivas de estas deudas podia promulgar leyes pero no podia ponerlas en vigor.

Los dirigente del nuevo pais comprendieron que debia haber una Constitucion, es decir una base de gobierno. En el verano de 1787 se reunió en la ciudad de Filadelfia una Convención que tuvo como Presidente á Jorge Washington. Entre otros de las grandes personajes que asistieron á ella se contaban Robert Morris, Jams Madison y Alexander Hamilton.

La Convención se reunió en el mismo salón en que el Congreso Continental haba adoptado en 1776 la Declaracion de Independencia. En todo ese ardiente verano los representates trabajaron sin cesar con el fin de formular una ley suprema para la nación. Todos ellos abogaron por la unidad. A pesar de que George Washington hablo poco, su influencia fue muy poderosa. En una ocasion en que los, pasa la pagina28 delegados no podian llegar á un acuerdo el Genral Washington entró ala en la discusion. Muy poco discuros tan significado.

"Si para complacer al pueblo fueramos á ofrecerle lo que nosotros mismos cesuramos, como podriamos mas tarde defender nuestra labor? Sentemos aqui una norma que pueda servir á los eruditos y á los hombres honrados para corregir erreros; el asunto esta en las manos de Dios.” Asi nacio la Constitucion, que es el documento mas notable en la historia del Govierno.

Este documento quedo concluido el 17 de Septiembre de 1787, pero necesitó que nueve de las 13 Colonias estados lo ratificaran antes de que pudieran v convertirse en la ley fundadamental de la nacion. Finalmente, el 4 de Marzo de 1789 tuvimos nuestra Constitucion. El párrafo introductorio se llama "Preámbulo;" puesto que expresa las razones que hicieron necesaria la Constitucion:

div3.head: El Preambulo
div3.p: nosotros el pueblo de los E. U. A. á fin de hacer una unión mas perfeta, establecer la justicia, asegurar la - tranquilidad interior, atender á la defensa comun, promover el bienestar general y asegurar los beneficios de la libertad para nosotros mismos y para nuestros desendientes ordenamos y establecemos la presente Constitucion para los E.U.A.

div2.p: Entremos á estudiar ahora cada una de las partes del Preámbolo. “Nosotros el Pueblo de los E.U.”- nosotros formamos nuestro paispropio govierno el poder es nuestro, nosotros sancionamos esta Constitucion como ley fundadamental de la Nacion. A fin de hacer una union mas perfecta. Esta es hoy dia una unión estre cuarenta y ocho estados undependientes

Ella ha perdurado por espacio de 150 años y tiene en si facultades de inmenso valor para el Pueblo. El pueblo norteamericano estaba tan resuelto á mantener esta unión que luchó en una guerra para impedir que se dividiera “Para estableser la Justicia” En nuestro pais todas las personas son iguales ante la ley. Todos deben respetala. Contamos Con tribunales de justicia para proteger a los inocentes, Castigar á los culpables y ayudar al pueblo á ventilar sus diferencias por medio de leyes justas y pacificas. “Para asegurar la tranquilidad interior”. Esto tiene como fin mantener la paz dentro de pais, y asegurar “los medios para conservarla, La Constitucion garantizar la paz interna. Para atender á la defensa común “-De acuerdo con la Constitucion nuestro govierno mantiene un ejercito y una armada para defender el pais. El Congreso es la una autoridad que tiene facultad para declarar la guerra. El presidente de la Republica es el Comandante en Jefe del Ejército y de la Armada. Hoy dia Contamos tambien con la fuerza Aría, en estas dos armas Loas E.U. tienen haora una poderosa defenza. “para fumentar el Bienestar general”- El bienestar general significa la felecidad común del pueblo de los E.U. sin distinación de raza o color ó religion. Asegurar los beneficios de la Libertad para nosotros mismos y para nuestros decendientes,”

div2.head: La Declaracion de Independecia
div2.p: estatuyó que el Pueblo tienen ciertos derechos inalinables, asaber el derecho á la vida, á la Libertad y la busca de la felecidad. Nuestro pueblo tiene libertad para vivir su propia vida, siempre que respete los preceptos de la ley. La Constitución garantiza estos derechos y privilegios. El Govierno de los E.U. es una Gobierno Federal una U. de E. es una democracía que significa que el Pueblo es el gobernante llega al poder la culpa es del pueblo que lo eligio.

Es una Republica lo que se ingnifica que el pueblo no gobierno directamente el pais sino que ejerce el sufragio para elegir á los hombres y mujeres que han de reprecentarlo en el poder. Nota: no confunda las palabras Republicana y Democracia con los apelativos Replublicanos y Demócrata. The Birth of the U.S was by virtue of the discovery made by Christopher Columbus on October 12, 1942. This country was later named the U.S.A. and was populated. Other voyagers had disembarked in this continent but had never established a colony before. The money for Columbus’ trip was supplied by Queen Isabella I of Spain.
More than one hundred years passed before the true settlers arrived and settled in these regions that they christened with the name of the colonies. These colonies later became the U.S.A.

The majority of the colonist came from England. The king continued to be their sovereign even after they had disembarked in this country, and so English came to be the national language. Some Dutch colonist settled in what is now New York, some Swedish colonist did so in Delaware, and many Germans settled in Pennsylvania. At the same time, there were Scottish and Irish citizens in all the colonies.

The English established their first colony in Jamestown, in the state of Virginia, in 1607. They crossed the Atlantic Ocean in the winter, making the voyage in three small ships named the Sarah Constant, Godspeed, and the Discovery. A hundred and five settlers made the voyage in those ships, commanded by Captain Christopher Newport. Later, after disembarking, the colonist lived under the brave and famous Captain John Smith’s command. It took the settlers four months to cross the ocean. They were lashed by various storms and they suffered countless obstacles in the voyage. Finally, on April 26, they arrived in the beaches of Virginia and they continued navigating from there,
Page 14 navigating for a hundred and sixty kilometers across the Chesapeake Bay and upstream the James River in search of an adequate site in which they could establish a colony. On May 13th they found the desired site and named it Jamestown in honor of King James of England. They landed there, and immediately started to form their own government.

This part of the country was only inhibited by Indians and wild animals, and there were neither cities, nor villages or houses. All there was were overgrown forest, swamps, and the wide river that flew stately in its vicinity. At dusk, in the middle of a great grove, the voyagers cut a giant tree and used its trunk to construct an altar on it, and from the branches of another tree they hung a sail to form a banner, and they celebrated a religious service. That is how with the forming of a government and collaboration of a the first permanent English colony was born in America.

It was not very long before the settlers experienced setbacks and suffered sufferings again. Soon they learned that they would only survive if they worked hard, and that they had to cut trees, plow the land, cultivate the soil, and grow corn. They had not brought their wives or children to help them build houses, and soon they ran out of the supplies that they had brought from England. At first, they could not produce enough corn to provide for their survival. Then came a terrible period of hunger and devastation that they called “The Hunger Hour” and so in which many died, and many others were killed by Indians. Desperate with so many setbacks they resolved to return to their country, and when they got closer to the river mouth they found an English ship that was carrying supplies. This was their salvation.

And from there on the colony of Jamestown started to flourish and prosper. In little time other colonies were set and the number of settlers
Page 15 arriving from England increased. The great colony of Virginia was definitely founded in 1619 and their people celebrated the first representative assembly in America. Every one of those colonies designated two of their members to represent them. The assembly took place in Jamestown and it issued the laws that should govern the destiny of the colony. Because the English firmly believed in the democratic government, they brought their laws and their free institutions with them.

The “Pilgrim Fathers” founded the second permanent English colony in 1620 in Plymouth, state of Massachusetts. They came to the U.S to find a place where they could worship God according to their beliefs, as they could not do in England. They sailed from the English port of Plymouth in a small boat that they called the Mayflower. On an icy day in the month of December they disembarked on the rocky coast of New England. No white man came to greet them when they landed, and, from the very beginning, they had to start building houses to shelter themselves with their wives and children.

Life was very difficult in the first years, but they were willing to face sufferings as long as they could worship God according to their beliefs. Because they were convinced that the Almighty's hand was guiding them, their faith gave them strength to bear the sufferings and the hardships. The U.S. always honored the memory of those pilgrims because they brought their love of freedom with them, and because they relentlessly suffered to spread this love in American soil. This love of freedom is what has made this prosperous country free and great. Let's now see what was this idea of liberty that the pilgrims adhere to. They believed that the People had the right and the ability to promulgate the laws. They believed
too that these laws aim at the general good, this is, at the benefit of everyone, and so everyone had to obey them as they were dictated by the nation itself. True freedom respects the rights of others and that was the freedom that the pilgrims were looking for in the U.S., as they preferred to suffer great setbacks instead of losing it.

In the span of 150, England's thirteen colonies along the coast of the Atlantic Ocean grew and flourished. Many of the laws in these colonies had no representation. They thought it was unfair that they had to obey laws dictated without their consent, and when King George III tried to govern England and the United States on a despotic fashion, they raised and started a war in April 1775. The colonist fought courageously during six terrible years under the command of distinguished general George Washington, who northern Americans today fairly call Father of the Nation. The famous French generals Lafayette and Rochambeau join them, and later France sent an army and a navy to help them. Other foreigners that helped our soldiers were the German Steuben, the Bavarian DeKalb, and the Polish Kosciusko. Independence from England was finally won, and the peace agreement was signed in 1783. The goal of this Independence War was to maintain the principles of colonial governments and to maintain the freedom that George III had tried to restrict.

Northern Americans hated those revolutions that tend to destroy, to overthrow, to kill, to loot, or to burn down. This victory transformed the thirteen independent colonies on what today is the U.S.A., governed by the Constitution. That was the meaning of the Northern American Revolution or the Independence War.

div2.head: The Declaration of Independence
div2.p: This declaration was made by the thirteen original states of the U.S.A. and passed on July 4, 1776 by the Continental Congress that gathered in the city of Philadelphia, in the state of Pennsylvania. The Declaration begins by expressing the reasons why the United States, composed then by only thirteen states, were forced to separate from Great Britain, their Motherland:

“We hold as an absolute truths that all men have been created equally by nature, that their Creator grants everyone certain inalienable rights, including life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. In order to ensure these rights, men have established governments and a legitimate power of consent is derived from them. Whenever a form of government becomes an instrument for destruction, the people have the right to change or abolish it and create a new government on its place."
1. All men are born the same. God granted them certain rights that cannot be removed; the main of these principles are life, freedom, and happiness.
2. To enjoy these rights, men establish governments that derive the powers of the consent of those that established it.

div2.head: Cradle of Independence
div2.p: There is a simple, very old brick building, topped with a tower, on Chestnut Street of the city of Philadelphia, state of Pennsylvania. In there, George Washington was designated commander and chief of the military that fought in the War of Independence and that obtained the victory. The Declaration of Independence was signed in this same site. Its commandments were read on its stairs. Our ancestors created and also constituted the Charter of Rights that governs us, this is, the Constitution of the U.S.A. In that same building you can see the Liberty Bell that announced the commission of independence to the world. This historical house is a revered shrine by all North Americans.

div2.head: The Flag of the United States
div2.p: The U.S. flag, which is sometimes called The Stars and Stripes, has red and six white stripes that represent the thirteen original states. It has a blue background with forty-eight stars that represent forty-eight states that are part of the republic.

“We have taken the stars and the blue from the sky, and the red we took from our homeland, separating it with white stripes to show that we separated from it. The white stripes will always represent freedom,” said George Washington talking about the flag that he himself helped design for the nation. Even before the Declaration of Independence was signed this flag had been already projected and it was accepted by the Congress of the U.S. on July 4th, 1777, by the following statement:

A new constellation had been born and all its faith and hopes are symbolized in its flag. Because of this, everyone has to pay attention and salute the flag when it passes in procession or a revision.

Men shall take off their hats, women shall put their right hand over their heart, and those wearing a uniform shall salute it raising their right hand towards their kepi. Just like there are courtesy and etiquette rules for people, there are also rules to honor our country and defend its ideals. Old, torn or dirty flags should be burnt and never be abandoned or use them in any other
Page 22 disrespectful manner. Never let the flag touch the ground and make sure that it is always flapping and free. And never use it as a pending or decoration. The flag should always be occupying the honorable position: on the right of the marching line or in front of any flags in a procession, to the right of a public speaker when it is displayed in a stand or when it faces the auditorium, to the right of the auditorium when raised at the same level. The flag should be flown at half-mast as a sign of mourning. For this purpose, first, the flag has to be raised to the top of the flagpole for a moment, and, then, lowered to the middle of it.

The flag should never be unfolded except between sunrise and sunset. It flaps over the U.S. Capitol continuously and it is not lowered except when it has to be replaced with a new one. It also flaps over any of the chambers when the Congress is in session, and in the White House when the president is in. It can remain hoisted at all hours in time of war. This flag is the symbol of Liberty, Justice, and Equality opportunity for all men, women, and children. The flag is often and fondly called “Old Glory.”

div2.head: The coat of arms of the U.S.A.
div2.p: On signing the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776, John Hancock, president of the Continental Congress, said: “Now that we are a nation, I would like to know your opinion over the following [issue]: Be it resolved, that Dr. Franklin, and Mr. Thomas Jefferson and Mr. John Adams set up a commission in charge of creating a model for the coat of arms of the U.S.A.” This great seal has the date in which it was authorized stamped, the 4th of July, 1776. It has thirteen stripes that represent the 13 states originally represented in Congress. The eagle with an olive branch in the right claw Pass to page 26 and a bundle with thirteen arrows on the left symbolizes that the U.S. prefer peace but are still prepared for war. In the beak, the eagle]= clutches a scroll with the motto “E Pluribus Unum” that means “Strength through Unity,” this is, that the government is formed by many states. This is the motto of the U.S.A. The thirteen-star declaration constellation that forms on the clouds at the top symbolizes the birth of a new nation. On the reverse, there is an incomplete pyramid with an eye that oversees everything, and with the words “Annuit Coeptis” – “He has favored our agreement”. The date of July 4, 1776 is on the base of the pyramid and the motto “Novus Ordo Seclorum”, “A new order of the ages,” is underneath. This is how a nation started under the protection of the divine providence. This seal is on all official documents. It symbolizes the nation's faith.

div2.head: The Government of the United States, The Constitution
div2.p:
During the Independence War, the new nation formed an association controlled by the so-called Articles of Confederation. The states continued to be represented by an assembly of citizens called Continental Congress. Once the war was over, they realized that this form of government was too weak. The states were not truly united. Every one of them aspired to exercise a great power. Their efforts were not united: Each of them had their own coin and their own laws regarding their trade with other states,
Continues on page 27 which resulted in great confusion.

The new nation needed money to cover the costs of the military and the army as well as to pay the debt contracted during the war. The Congress did not have the authority to obligate states to pay their respective share of this debt. Given that the nation did not have a government, this is, they didn't have a president in Congress did not have the authority to obligate states to pay their respective share of these debts, they could pass laws but they could not implement them.

The leaders of the new country understood that they needed a constitution, this is, a basis for a government. In the summer of 1787, a convention that had George Washington as president met in the city of Philadelphia. Among some of the very well known people that were in the meeting we find Robert Morris, James Madison, and Alexander Hamilton.

The convention was held in the same room in which the Continental Congress had adopted the Declaration of Independence in 1779. During that scalding summer, the representatives worked incessantly to form a supreme law for the nation. All of them made the case for unity. Though George Washington said little, his influence was very powerful. Once, when Continues on page 28 the delegates could not come to an agreement, General Washington entered the discussion. Very few speeches have been so significant:

“If we were to offer the People what we ourselves censor in order to to please them, how could we later on defend our work? Let's set a norm that the experts and the honorable men can use to correct mistakes; the issue is in God's hands.” That is how the Constitution, the most notable document in the Government's history, was born.

The document was completed on September 17, 1787, but nine of the thirteen states had to ratify it before it could become a national fundamental law. Finally, on March 4, 1789 we had our Constitution. The introductory paragraph is called the Preamble as it expresses the reasons why the Constitution was necessary.

div3.head: The Preamble
div3.p: “We, the People of the U.S.A., in order to form a more perfect Union, to establish Justice, to insure domestic Tranquility, to provide for the common defence, to promote the general Welfare, and to secure the Blessings of Liberty to ourselves and our Posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the U.S.A.”

div2.p: Let's study now every one of the parts of the Preamble: “We the people of the U.S.” We formed our country own government, we hold the power, we sanctioned this Constitution as the national fundamental law in order to create a more perfect union. This is a union of forty-eight independent states today.

It has been in place for a span of 150 years and it holds authority of immense value for the people. The North American people were so determined to maintain this unity that they fought a war to stop its division. “To establish Justice” In our country everyone is equal before the law. Everyone has to respect it. We have the Court of Law to protect the innocent, to punish the guilty, and to help the people to address their differences through just and orderly laws. “To insure domestic Tranquility” This is to maintain peace in the country, and to ensure “the means to insure it, the Constitution guarantees domestic peace. To attend the common defense.” According to the Constitution our government supports an army and a navy to defend the country. Congress is the only authority that has the ability to declare war. The president of the Republic is the Commander in Chief of the army and navy. Today we also have the Air Force, and with both weapons the U.S. now hold a powerful defense. “To promote the general Welfare” The general welfare means the common happiness of the people of the U.S. without distinction of race, color, or religion. “To secure the Blessings of Liberty to ourselves and our Posterity.”

div2.head: The Declaration of Independence
div2.p: It enacted that the People have certain unalienable Rights, among them, the right to Life, Liberty and the pursuit of Happiness. Our People has the liberty to live their own life as long as they respect the law. The Constitution guarantees these rights and privileges. The U.S. Government is a Federal government. A union of states conforms a democracy, this is, the People are the government and they are at fault of the leader that is elected.

It is a Republic, this is, the People do not directly rule the country, rather, they exercise common suffrage to elect men and women who represent them in power. Note: Do not confuse the words Republic and Democracy with the Republican and Democratic designations. These are the names of political parties and it does not mean that they form the government. The Constitution authorizes three governmental powers, namely:

list.item: 1. The first one, the Legislative power that promulgates the laws.
2. The Executive power, with the president at the head, assures the laws are complied to and respected (and cabinet)
3. The Judicial power interprets the laws and decides Matters of Law.

div2.p: When Congress issues a law, the President has the ability to veto it, in other words, to say that it is not approved. If Congress wishes to, they can vote again on this law and if two thirds parts of its members approves it, it passes. In fact, it becomes a law of the nation over the president’s veto. The Supreme Court of the U.S. can declare a law unconstitutional, this is, that it is against the Constitution. Its objective is to prevent the absolute authority of those three governmental powers. We call this a “checks and balance” system. It constitutes a safeguard for the People. Congress is held annually in the city of Washington, on January 3rd. This body has to pass laws. It is divided into two chambers: senators and representatives.
The president of the Republic has the authority to convene Congress to special sessions.

There is a total of 96 Senators. They are elected at a rate of two per state, for a period of six years. To be a senator Next Page 31 one must be at least 30 years old and have been a citizen of the country for at least nine years.

They have to be residents of the state in which they are elected. There are 435 Representatives, one for every 304,000 inhabitants in their state. The representatives are elected for periods of two years and have to be at least 25 years of age, and have been citizens for at least seven years. The President of the U.S. is elected for four years. The Constitution does not say how many times a President can be re-elected. He takes office on January 20th of the following year after the election. He must be a citizen by birth, be at least 35 years old and have lived in the U.S. for 14 consecutive years. The president is not elected directly by the People, who votes for their the constituents in the general elections in every state. Later on, they assemble and elect the President. As said before, he is the Commander in Chief of the military and the air force that is part of the two branches. The President has the authority to make treaties or agreements with other nations and to name certain officers. The Senate has to bestow its approval of the treaties or agreements and appointments made by the Executive armies. The Vice President has to meet the same qualities as the President. He is responsible for taking hold of the presidency of the Senate in case of removal, death, resignation, or inability both of the President or the Vice President, in which case the chair of House of Representatives will become the President. The President names a group of nine advisors that form the Executive Cabinet, but the nominations must be approved by the Senate.

The highest court of the nation is the Supreme Court of Justice with its headquarters in the City of Washington. It is made up by judges, one of which is the president of it. The judges are appointed by the president of the Republic with the approval of the Senate and their positions are for life. The Supreme Court is the only Federal Court provided on the Constitution. div2.head: Human Rights
div2.p: The first ten amendments of the Constitution are the so-called Human Rights. The People would not have adopted the Constitution unless they were guaranteed these rights. They had fought to obtain these freedoms, and had triumphed; therefore they did not want to risk losing them. The Human Rights were the first thing that Congress accounted. When these were approved, a day of grace was designated.

Today, the People is responsible for the compliance of those rights. If anyone is denied a right, then everyone shall have it denied. Congress cannot approve any law to establish a religion. No one is denied freedom of speech or press as long as they don’t say falsehoods that could offend someone, nor the right of the people to peacefully gather and to ask the government for the reparation of their grievances. These are the first demands on the Fundamental Law. The Federal Government cannot stop the right of the people to a free state and to carry guns, and no one can host a soldier in their houses without the proprietor’s permission. Their home should be protected against irrational searches and hijacking unless supported by reasonable cause It continues on page 34 in an oath or statement that clearly designates the place that has to be searched and the people or things that have to be taken. The property cannot be exposed without a fair compensation. No one can be forced to respond to a subjected to court twice for the same crime. No one can be obligated to declare against themselves. They will have the opportunity to communicate with the witnesses who declared against them and they can obtain ordinances to obtain witnesses in their favor. They cannot be deprived of liberty except with valid legal grounds.

The accused should be told about the reason and the cause of the accusation, he/she shall enjoy the right to a quick and public trial, by an impartial jury of the state and district in which the crime shall have been committed, and to have the assistance of a lawyer for his/her defense. Excessive bails cannot be demanded and no excessive fines or cruel and unusual punishments can be given. The Human Rights state that other rights that are not mentioned do also belong to the People, and that the abilities that have not been delegated or have not been prohibited to the states by the Constitution of the U.S are respectively reserved for the states or for the People.

div3.head: Human Rights The First Amendment,Freedom of religion, speech, and press.
div3.p: Congress shall make no law that establishes a religion or prohibits the free exercise of it; or that limits the freedom of speech, press; or the right of the people to peaceably assemble, and to ask the government for a redress of grievances.

div3.head: Second3 Amendment for the Accommodation of Soldiers
div3.p: In time of peace, no soldier can be quartered in any house without the consent of the owners, and, in time of war, they can only do it in a manner to be prescribed by law.

div3.head: ThirdAmendment 2. The Right to Have and Bare Arms.
div3.p: A well regulated militia is necessary for the security of a free state, and the right to have and carry arms cannot be infringed.

div3.head: Amendment 4. Protection Against Irrational Searchers and Seizures.
div3.p: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and belonging, against irrational searches and seizures should not be violated, and no warrant shall be issued for it except because of reasonable cause, supported by oath or affirmation that clearly designates the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

div3.head: Fifth Amendment. The Rights of the Accused in Criminal Proceedings.
div3.p: No person shall be obligated to respond to a capital or infamous crime unless reported or indicted by a Grand Jury, except in cases that occurs in the land or naval forces or in the Militia, when they are in active duty in time of war or public danger. No person shall be subject for the same crime twice that could cause them to lose their life or some limb, nor shall be compelled to testify against himself in any criminal case, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property without due legal process, nor shall private property be taken away for public use without just compensation.

div3.head: Sixth Amendment. Trial by jury, the Right to a speedy jury trial, witness, etc.
div3.p: In all criminal prosecutions, the accused has the right to a public speedy trial with an impartial jury of the State and of the district in which the crime was committed, which district shall have beforehand determined law, and to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation; to be confronted with the witnesses that testify against him; and to be informed about the obligatory actions taken against him; and to have compulsory process to obtain witness in his favor, and to have a lawyer that defends him.

div3.head: Seventh Amendment. Trial by jury in civilian cases.
div3.p: In lawsuits at common law, when the value of the controversial material exceeds twenty dollars, the right to a trial by jury shall be kept, and if the jury reaches no decision, it shall be subject to a new examination by any court of the U.S.A in accordance with the rules of the common law.

div3.head: Eighth Amendment. Bail, fines, and punishment.
div3.p: Excessive bail shall not be demanded nor shall excessive fines be imposed, nor shall cruel or unusual punishment be inflicted.

div3.head: Ninth Amendment. Bill of Rights for the People.
div3.p: The list of certain rights in the Constitution shall not be interpreted to deny or restrict other rights retained by the People.

div3.head: Tenth Amendment. States' Rights.
div3.p: The rights that have not been delegated by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the respective states or to the people.

The first ten amendments were all proposed by Congress on September 25, 1789, and ratified and adopted on December 15, 1791. The Constitution has been amended twenty one times and the first ten amendments make up the Human Rights.

It establishes the benefit of a stable and responsible government. It recognizes those born in the country as U.S. citizens. It grants the privilege of citizenship to foreigners. It does not obligate one to answer for any major crime charges unless one has been legally charged. div2.head: The Governments of the States
div2.p: When the thirteen colonies declared their Independence from Great Britain in 1776, they became independent states from the Great. Some of them continued to be governed through the constitutions adopted by the People during a certain period. From time to time new states were admitted to the Union. Today all of them have constitutions sanctioned by the People. The state government is also divided into the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial branches. The legislatures of the states enact their own laws and each of them is comprised of two Chambers that are commonly known as the Senate and the Assembly. The members of these legislatures are directly elected by the states. The Executive branch monitors that the laws are in effect and compiled by the legislature. People elect the executive chief, called the Governor, for a period that ranges between one to four years in the different states. Under their address, the various departments are in charge of diverse branches of laws such as agriculture, labor, public finances, education, and military. Page 41 The Judicial branch of state courts has to apply laws to the various cases of their jurisdiction. These courts have distinctive names according the to the degree of the affairs that they are in charge of. There are courts for criminal affairs and others only for civil affairs in all of the states. There are also higher courts in which one can appeal the decisions of the lower courts.

The autonomy, this is, the self-government, is On the next page
Page 41 is it’s own one of fundamental principles of the North American Democracy so that anyone can take part in the collective or group government in which they live in. The states are divided counties.

The voters of each county elect their own officials in charge of affairs to which the laws correspond. There are more than 3000 counties of various sizes in the country, such as for example the Bristol County in the state of Massachusetts, which is 65 square kilometers the county while Custer County in the state of Montana has an area of 52,250 squared kilometers. The county constructs and preserves streets and bridges, sustains the almshouse and helps the state keep the peace and apprehend and punish criminals. Some counties carry out other functions. Town and city governments are another form of local government. In New England (Northeastern state) this form of government was developed by the first colonies as they lived in small, densely populated towns. The voters of the city and towns have absolute dominance over solely local affairs like schools and public health, streets, and public tranquility. They also elect the people that want to represent the group in the state Assembly. All men and women should be proud to know that they can participate in the government of the community Continues on next page

In any case, it has absolute freedom to exercise its authority in the same manner as any of the oldest. The national government does not have the power to destroy the states either.
